column1: What should we do in our house if it were not for our Aunt Matilda? She is the first one out of bed in the morning
column2: and the last one to go to bed at night. She sees that things are right in the kitchen
column3: and right in the parlor.Father wants his breakfast by half-past six o'clock this summer weather. Aunt Matilda rises before five
column5: and sees that the rooms are in order. Then she calls the children to be washed and dressed.Yes
column6: that is a good likeness of her
column7: as you see her combing my hair. She is not young
column9: nor yet very old. Sometimes I get a little impatient
column11: because she is so particular; but our quarrels always end in my kissing her
